Transparency.justification: Score = 1 because 3 source(s) (listed below) contain detailed, verifiable information.

relevantSources.title: CHRO Principles: Responsible Use of AI in Organizations
relevantSources.summary: Framework for responsible AI use emphasizing transparency and explainability in organizational contexts.

relevantSources.title: Perspectives on AI & HR: A Resource for HR Practitioners
relevantSources.summary: Comprehensive guidance on AI governance practices including transparency requirements for HR applications.

relevantSources.title: Challenges & Best Practices in Industrial Artificial Intelligence
relevantSources.summary: Technical blog discussing AI transparency requirements and explainable outputs for industrial applications.

Transparency.findings: General Electric provides detailed frameworks and technical discussions on AI transparency, including explicit requirements for transparent and explainable outputs in HR and industrial AI contexts. These sources demonstrate a commitment to transparency as a core principle in both organizational and technical practices.

relevantSources.summary: Discusses AI bias mitigation strategies and fairness considerations in HR applications.

relevantSources.summary: Details diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts including AI applications in healthcare contexts.

relevantSources.title: Sustainability Report Building a World That Works for Tomorrow
relevantSources.summary: Covers mitigating bias in talent processes and AI-driven clinical applications.

Fairness & Bias Mitigation.findings: GE's public documents provide concrete evidence of bias mitigation and fairness strategies in AI, particularly in HR and healthcare. The company outlines specific approaches to reduce bias and promote equity, supported by sustainability and HR governance reports.

Explainability.justification: Score = 1 because 2 source(s) (listed below) contain detailed, verifiable information.

relevantSources.summary: Technical requirements for explainable AI output to build trust in industrial applications.

relevantSources.summary: Discussion of explainable artificial intelligence algorithms and their development approaches.

Explainability.findings: GE provides technical and practical evidence of explainable AI methods, including requirements for explainable outputs and algorithm development. These sources show a clear focus on interpretability and trust in industrial AI systems.

relevantSources.title: CHRO Principles: Responsible Use of AI in Organizations
relevantSources.summary: Establishes human leadership requirements and accountability frameworks for AI initiatives.

relevantSources.title: Electrification Software Twin

relevantSources.summary: Emphasizes keeping humans as final decision-makers in AI systems.

Human Oversight & Accountability.findings: GE's artifacts provide concrete evidence of human oversight and accountability in AI, including defined leadership roles, human-in-the-loop mechanisms, and policies ensuring humans remain final decision-makers in critical processes.

Privacy & Security.findings: GE has published detailed policies and technical solutions for privacy and security in AI, including data protection plans and AI-driven cybersecurity tools for critical infrastructure, demonstrating robust practices in this area.

Governance & Accountability.findings: GE provides concrete evidence of formal AI governance structures, including cross-functional committees, compliance frameworks, and structured development processes, supporting organizational accountability for AI initiatives.

summary.overallFindings: General Electric Company demonstrates comprehensive and detailed responsible AI practices across all seven pillars. The company provides robust frameworks, technical documentation, and public commitments addressing transparency, fairness, explainability, human oversight, privacy, governance, and external accountability. GE's evidence base is strong, with verifiable sources supporting each area and no significant gaps identified.
